ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend it if you have a specific reason to study Iraqi. Otherwise, stick to Modern Standard. There is really no vocabulary expansion - the main focus is giving us the common-but-different-than-standard words and using them in context.

Iraqi Arabic is an introductory course in the Iraqi dialect; you'll learn basic, useful vocabulary that you may not have learned in Modern Standard. It's highly focused on words/phrases that can actually be used in conversation.

This is a solid intro course to Iraqi Ameeya. Don't take the class expecting to emerge as a fluent speaker, though; you'll understand most of the basic expressions used on a daily basis, but it will still be difficult to speak fluently in Ameeya. The work load is relatively light, about 4-5 hours all told per week. The listening drills could be a bit of apain, but if you power through them it does help you.

If you want to actually speak Arabic, you need a colloquial dialect. Iraqi is a good dialect to learn and Usteza al Ani is a really wonderful teacher. She is sweet and a fair grader and the work is not at all overwhelming (10-40 minutes of homework per class + some quizzes and tests over the course of the semester).
